prompt.content:
One type of beetle has 3 possible wing colors, blue, green and turquoise. Randomly caught individuals of a polymorphic population were crossed with each other.
It is a monohybrid inheritance with three alleles, B, G & T. Dominance: B > G > T
You get the parent phenotype, and the distribution of phenotypes in the F1 - generation. State the genotypes of the parents and offspring as accurately as possible. No further explanation necessary. If a given distribution is impossible, state 'impossible'.
Example task:
Blue x Blue -> 4/4 Blue
Example solution:
BB (Blue) x B_ (Blue) -> 4/4 B_ (Blue)
Example Task:
Blue x Blue -> 3/4 Blue 1/4 Green
Example Solution:
BG (Blue) x BG (Blue) -> 1/4 BB (Blue), 1/2 BG (Green), 1/4 GG (Green)
Blue x Blue -> 3/4 Blue 1/4 Turquoise

options: Bt (Blue) x BT (Blue) -> 1/4 BB (Blue), 1/2 BT (Blue), 1/4 TT (Turquoise)

data.sampled:
:
This is not possible. Dominant Turquoise allele would be incompatible with the recessive Blue allele, resulting in all individuals inheriting only Turquoise. The ratio of dominant and recessive variants would be 2:0, which cannot be achieved in a blend of two phenotypically distinct populations.<|im_end|>

data.sampled: : This distribution is impossible. There is no way to produce a homozygote for the green allele as the blue allele is dominant over the green allele. Therefore, all offspring would be expected to inherit either two blue alleles or one blue allele and one green allele. (3/4 Blue, 1/4 Green)<|im_end|>

data.expected: GT x GT -> 1/4 GG, 1/2 GT, 1/4 TT
data.sampled:
: The possible combinations of alleles are:
GG = Homozygous dominant (thick allele)
GG = Homozygous recessive (thin allele)
GT = Heterozygous (thick allele + thin allele)
For Green x Green, since it is also a monohybrid inheritance with three alleles, the possible combinations of alleles are:
GG, GT or GG
Since there are only two individuals in the population (the crossed parent), we can't determine the dominance relationship between the alleles. Therefore, it is not possible to determine the genotypes of the individuals or the distribution of phenotypes in the F1 generation.<|im_end|>

prompt.content:
One type of beetle has 3 possible wing colors, blue, green and turquoise. Randomly caught individuals of a polymorphic population were crossed with each other.
It is a monohybrid inheritance with three alleles, B, G & T. Dominance: B > G > T
You get the parent phenotype, and the distribution of phenotypes in the F1 - generation. State the genotypes of the parents and offspring as accurately as possible. No further explanation necessary. If a given distribution is impossible, state 'impossible'.
Example task:
Blue x Blue -> 4/4 Blue
Example solution:
BB x B_ -> 4/4 B_
Example Task:
Blue x Blue -> 3/4 Blue 1/4 Green
Example Solution:
BG x BG -> 1/4 BB, 1/2 BG, 1/4 GG
Green x Green -> 3/4 Green 1/4 Turquoise

options: GT x GT -> 1/4 GG, 1/2 GT, 1/4 TT

data.sampled:
:
In this case, both parents have the B allele for blue pigment in their wings. The F1 generation individuals will each have a 50% chance of inheriting the B allele for blue pigment from either parent, resulting in a 4/4 ratio of blue-pigment individuals in the F1 population. The genotype for parent 1 would be BB (Blue) and the genotype for parent 2 would be B_. The offspring would have the genotype BB_ (Blue). Therefore, the possible genotypes for this scenario are BB, BB_, B_, and B_, and the offspring will be heterozygous with 2 B alleles. Since the genotype BB is dominant over B_ and B, the distribution of phenotypes in the F1 generation will be 4/4 Blue, which is not possible.<|im_end|>

data.expected: BG x BG -> 1/4 BB, 1/2 BG, 1/4 GG
data.sampled:
:
Genotypes of parents:
- Blue B dominant over Green G
Genotypes of offspring:
- BB homozygotes: 3/4 B, 1/4 BB
- B_ heterozygotes: 3/4 B + 1/4 G
- G_ heterozygotes: 1/4 GB
Predicted distribution in F1:
- BB homozygotes: 4/8
- B_ heterozygotes: 8/32
- G_ heterozygotes: 16/64
The predicted distribution is not possible, since there is no way to have 3/4 blue and 1/4 green in a single individual, and yet also have BB homozygotes and B_ heterozygotes together. After further investigation, it was determined that the F1 distribution was in fact impossible.<|im_end|>
